name: プロテイン
description: Protein is the fundamental macronutrient essential for virtually every biological process in the human body, serving as the primary building blocks for muscle tissue, enzymes, hormones, antibodies, and cellular structures. Composed of amino acids linked together in specific sequences, proteins perform countless critical functions including tissue repair and growth, immune system support, nutrient transport, fluid balance regulation, and energy production when carbohydrates and fats are insufficient. The human body requires approximately 20 different amino acids to function properly, with nine classified as essential amino acids that must be obtained through diet since the body cannot synthesize them in adequate amounts. High-quality complete proteins contain all essential amino acids in optimal ratios for human utilization, primarily found in animal sources like meat, fish, eggs, and dairy, while plant-based proteins often lack one or more essential amino acids, requiring strategic combinations to achieve complete amino acid profiles. Protein requirements vary significantly based on age, sex, activity level, health status, and specific goals - sedentary adults need approximately 0.8 grams per kilogram of body weight daily for basic maintenance, while athletes, older adults, and individuals in caloric deficit may require 1.6-2.2 grams per kilogram to optimize performance, preserve lean mass, and support recovery. Beyond muscle building, adequate protein intake supports satiety and weight management by reducing hunger hormones and increasing metabolic rate through the thermic effect of food, enhances bone health by improving calcium absorption and bone mineral density, supports healthy aging by preventing sarcopenia (age-related muscle loss), and maintains optimal immune function through antibody production and immune cell synthesis. With growing recognition of protein's multifaceted roles in health, longevity, and disease prevention, understanding optimal protein intake, timing, quality, and sources has become foundational knowledge for anyone seeking to optimize their nutrition, body composition, athletic performance, or overall wellness.
benefits: Stimulates muscle protein synthesis and supports muscle growth, repair, and recovery, with resistance training combined with adequate protein (1.6-2.2g/kg) increasing muscle mass by 0.5-2kg per month in trained individuals

Enhances satiety and reduces hunger by increasing levels of satiety hormones (GLP-1, peptide YY) while decreasing ghrelin, leading to spontaneous calorie reduction of 200-400 calories daily in high-protein diets

Boosts metabolic rate through the thermic effect of food, with protein requiring 20-30% of its calories for digestion and processing compared to 5-10% for carbohydrates and 0-3% for fats, increasing daily calorie expenditure by 80-100 calories
Preserves lean muscle mass during caloric restriction and weight loss, with higher protein intakes (1.8-2.4g/kg) preserving 20-30% more lean mass compared to standard protein intake during fat loss

Supports bone health by improving calcium absorption, increasing bone mineral density, and reducing fracture risk, with studies showing 10-20% reduction in hip fracture risk with higher protein intake in older adults
Accelerates wound healing and tissue repair by providing essential amino acids for collagen synthesis, immune cell production, and cellular regeneration following injury, surgery, or illness

Maintains healthy blood pressure by improving endothelial function and supporting nitric oxide production, with research indicating 2-5 mmHg reductions in blood pressure with increased protein consumption
Supports healthy aging and prevents sarcopenia, the age-related loss of muscle mass and strength that accelerates after age 50, with adequate protein slowing muscle loss by up to 40% in older adults

Enhances immune function by providing amino acids necessary for antibody production, immune cell proliferation, and cytokine synthesis, particularly important during illness, stress, or intensive training

Improves athletic performance and recovery by reducing exercise-induced muscle damage markers by 20-40%, decreasing muscle soreness, and accelerating return to peak performance between training sessions
recommendedDosage: Protein requirements vary substantially based on individual factors including age, sex, body composition, activity level, health status, and specific goals. For sedentary adults, the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) is 0.8 grams per kilogram of body weight daily (approximately 56g for a 70kg adult), though many nutrition scientists consider this a minimum to prevent deficiency rather than an optimal intake for health. Active individuals and athletes benefit from higher intakes - endurance athletes typically need 1.2-1.6g/kg daily, while strength and power athletes optimally consume 1.6-2.2g/kg to maximize muscle protein synthesis and recovery. Older adults (65+ years) require higher protein intakes of 1.2-1.5g/kg to combat age-related muscle loss and maintain functional capacity, with some research suggesting benefits up to 1.6-2.0g/kg for optimal sarcopenia prevention. During caloric restriction or fat loss phases, protein requirements increase to 1.8-2.7g/kg of body weight to preserve lean muscle mass, with higher intakes at the lower end of body fat percentage. For optimal muscle protein synthesis, distribute protein intake across 3-5 meals providing 20-40 grams of high-quality protein per meal, as this distribution stimulates muscle protein synthesis more effectively than consuming the same total amount in fewer larger meals. Post-exercise protein consumption of 20-40 grams within 2 hours of training enhances recovery and adaptation, though the anabolic window may extend 4-6 hours or longer. Pre-sleep protein consumption (30-40 grams of slow-digesting protein like casein) can enhance overnight muscle protein synthesis and improve next-day recovery. Protein quality matters significantly - animal proteins (meat, fish, eggs, dairy) provide complete amino acid profiles with high biological value and absorption rates of 90-95%, while plant proteins often have lower biological values (70-85%) and may require larger amounts or strategic combining to achieve equivalent amino acid delivery. Very high protein intakes exceeding 2.5-3.0g/kg are generally unnecessary for most individuals and provide minimal additional benefits while potentially displacing other important nutrients.
sideEffects: Protein is generally safe and well-tolerated at recommended intakes, though excessive consumption or rapid increases may cause side effects in some individuals. Digestive discomfort including bloating, gas, and changes in bowel movements affects approximately 10-20% of people when dramatically increasing protein intake, particularly from dairy proteins like whey or from high-fiber plant proteins - gradual increases over 2-3 weeks typically minimize these effects. Individuals with pre-existing kidney disease or significantly impaired kidney function should moderate protein intake and consult nephrologists, as very high protein intake may accelerate kidney function decline in compromised kidneys, though extensive research confirms that normal to moderately high protein intake (up to 2.0-2.5g/kg) does not harm healthy kidney function. Dehydration risk may increase slightly with very high protein intake due to increased nitrogen metabolism and urea excretion, requiring adequate fluid consumption of at least 35-40ml per kilogram of body weight daily. Some individuals experience nausea or appetite suppression with high protein intake, particularly when consumed in large single meals rather than distributed throughout the day. Certain protein sources may trigger allergies or intolerances - dairy proteins affect lactose-intolerant individuals, while egg and soy proteins are common allergens requiring alternative sources. Gout-prone individuals should moderate intake of high-purine protein sources like organ meats, certain fish, and red meat, though moderate protein intake from most sources does not typically trigger gout attacks. Constipation may occur when increasing protein intake if fiber and fluid intake are inadequate, as protein-dense foods often displace higher-fiber options - ensure adequate vegetable consumption and hydration. Very high protein intake combined with very low carbohydrate consumption may cause temporary fatigue or reduced exercise performance during adaptation periods lasting 1-3 weeks. Bad breath (halitosis) can occur with very high protein intake, particularly ketogenic approaches, due to protein metabolism byproducts - adequate hydration and oral hygiene help minimize this effect.
interactions: Protein intake and timing can influence medication absorption, nutrient status, and various physiological processes requiring consideration in specific circumstances. Levodopa (L-dopa) medications for Parkinson's disease compete with dietary amino acids for absorption in the intestines and transport across the blood-brain barrier - separating protein intake from medication dosing by 30-60 minutes or redistributing protein intake away from medication timing can improve drug effectiveness and symptom control. Thyroid hormone medications (levothyroxine) may have reduced absorption when taken with protein-rich foods or supplements, particularly those containing soy protein, calcium, or iron - take thyroid medication on an empty stomach at least 30-60 minutes before protein consumption. Bisphosphonate medications for osteoporosis require separation from protein-rich meals by at least 30 minutes to ensure adequate absorption. Calcium absorption may be enhanced by moderate protein intake through improved intestinal absorption, but extremely high protein intake (above 2.5g/kg) may slightly increase urinary calcium excretion, though this rarely causes problems when calcium intake is adequate (1,000-1,200mg daily). Iron absorption from plant-based sources (non-heme iron) is significantly enhanced when consumed with animal proteins containing heme iron or with vitamin C, while calcium and certain plant compounds (phytates, polyphenols) can reduce iron absorption when consumed simultaneously. Vitamin B12 absorption requires adequate stomach acid and intrinsic factor, both of which may be reduced in older adults or those taking acid-reducing medications - these individuals may require higher protein intakes from B12-rich animal sources or supplementation. High protein intake may slightly increase requirements for B vitamins (particularly B6, folate, and B12) needed for amino acid metabolism, though typical diets usually provide adequate amounts. Alcohol metabolism may be slightly slowed when consumed with protein-rich meals due to delayed gastric emptying, potentially reducing peak blood alcohol levels but extending duration of elevation. Fiber-rich plant proteins may slightly reduce absorption of certain minerals including zinc and magnesium due to phytate content, though this is rarely clinically significant with varied diets. Protein powder supplements may interact with certain medications if they contain added ingredients like herbs, stimulants, or other bioactive compounds - always check complete ingredient lists and consult healthcare providers about potential interactions.
scientificBackground: Proteins are complex macromolecules composed of amino acids linked by peptide bonds in sequences determined by genetic coding, with structures ranging from simple linear chains to highly organized three-dimensional configurations essential for biological function. The twenty standard amino acids combine in countless sequences to create the estimated 80,000-400,000 different proteins in the human body, each with specific roles in enzymatic catalysis, structural support, cell signaling, immune defense, transport, and countless other functions. Muscle protein synthesis (MPS), the process of building new muscle proteins, is activated by mechanical tension from resistance exercise and amino acid availability, particularly leucine, which activates the mTOR (mechanistic target of rapamycin) signaling pathway at concentrations of approximately 2.5-3 grams per meal. Research published in the Journal of the International Society of Sports Nutrition demonstrates that 20-40 grams of high-quality protein maximally stimulates MPS in most individuals, with higher amounts (40+ grams) beneficial for larger individuals or after whole-body resistance training. The muscle full effect describes the phenomenon where muscle protein synthesis plateaus approximately 3-5 hours after protein consumption, after which muscle becomes refractory to further amino acid stimulation until protein breakdown resets sensitivity - this explains why distributing protein across multiple meals more effectively stimulates daily muscle protein synthesis than consuming equivalent amounts in fewer meals. Protein digestibility-corrected amino acid score (PDCAAS) and the newer Digestible Indispensable Amino Acid Score (DIAAS) measure protein quality by assessing amino acid composition and digestibility - whey protein scores 1.0-1.09 (the maximum under PDCAAS), egg white 1.0, beef 0.92, soy 0.91, and wheat 0.42, indicating significant quality differences between sources. The leucine threshold hypothesis suggests that approximately 2.5-3 grams of leucine per meal optimally stimulates MPS, achievable through 20-30 grams of high-quality animal protein or 30-40 grams of most plant proteins. Protein turnover, the continuous breakdown and synthesis of body proteins, averages 250-300 grams daily in adults, with some tissues like intestinal lining and immune cells turning over completely within days, while structural proteins like collagen may persist for years. Essential amino acid availability is the primary limiting factor for protein synthesis - when even one essential amino acid is deficient, protein synthesis is limited regardless of other amino acid abundance, explaining the superiority of complete protein sources for muscle building and recovery.

faqs.question: How much protein do I really need per day, and does it differ based on my goals?
faqs.answer: Protein needs vary dramatically based on individual factors and specific goals, making personalized calculation important for optimal results. For general health maintenance in sedentary adults, the RDA of 0.8g/kg body weight (about 56g for a 70kg person) prevents deficiency but may be suboptimal for many people. For body composition improvement and general fitness, 1.2-1.6g/kg (84-112g for 70kg individual) better supports muscle maintenance, satiety, and metabolic health. Active individuals training regularly should target 1.6-2.2g/kg, with strength athletes at the higher end and endurance athletes at 1.2-1.6g/kg. During fat loss or caloric restriction, increase to 1.8-2.7g/kg to preserve lean muscle mass, with leaner individuals benefiting from higher intakes. Older adults (65+ years) should consume 1.2-2.0g/kg to combat age-related muscle loss, with emerging evidence suggesting 1.6g/kg as an optimal target for sarcopenia prevention. For muscle building in a caloric surplus, 1.6-2.2g/kg effectively maximizes muscle protein synthesis, with intakes above 2.4g/kg providing minimal additional benefits. Very high intakes exceeding 3.0g/kg are generally unnecessary and may displace other important nutrients without providing additional muscle-building advantages. To calculate your target, multiply your body weight in kilograms by the appropriate factor - for example, a 75kg strength athlete aiming for muscle gain would target 120-165g protein daily (75kg x 1.6-2.2g/kg).

faqs.question: Is it better to get protein from food or supplements, and when should I use protein powder?
faqs.answer: Whole food protein sources should form the foundation of your protein intake, as they provide not only amino acids but also vitamins, minerals, healthy fats, and other beneficial compounds that support overall health. Foods like chicken, fish, eggs, dairy, legumes, and whole grains offer nutritional synergy that isolated protein supplements cannot fully replicate. However, protein supplements like whey, casein, pea, or soy protein serve valuable roles in specific contexts: convenience when whole food preparation is impractical, rapid post-workout recovery when fast absorption is beneficial (whey absorbs within 30-60 minutes versus 2-3 hours for whole foods), precise protein dosing without excess calories during fat loss, meeting higher protein needs when appetite is limited, and pre-sleep muscle support using slow-digesting proteins like casein. Research shows that protein from food and supplements produces equivalent muscle protein synthesis responses when amino acid content is matched, making the source less important than total daily intake and distribution. An evidence-based approach uses whole foods for 70-80% of daily protein (ensuring micronutrient adequacy and food satisfaction), with strategic supplementation filling 20-30% for post-workout recovery, between-meal protein boosts, or convenience. For example, someone needing 150g daily protein might consume 100-120g from meals (chicken, fish, eggs, Greek yogurt, legumes) and 30-50g from 1-2 protein shakes timed around workouts or as snacks. Quality matters regardless of source - choose minimally processed, complete proteins when possible, and verify supplement quality through third-party testing (NSF Certified for Sport, Informed-Sport).

faqs.question: Does eating too much protein damage kidneys or cause other health problems?
faqs.answer: This is one of the most persistent nutrition myths, largely debunked by extensive research in individuals with healthy kidney function. High protein intake (up to 2.0-2.5g/kg body weight and beyond) does not cause kidney damage or dysfunction in people with normal kidney health, as confirmed by systematic reviews and long-term studies in athletes consuming 2.5-3.0g/kg for years without adverse kidney effects. When you consume protein, your kidneys filter increased nitrogen waste products (urea) from amino acid metabolism, causing higher glomerular filtration rate (GFR) - this is a normal adaptive response, not kidney damage or dysfunction, similar to how heart rate increases with exercise without indicating cardiac damage. However, individuals with pre-existing chronic kidney disease (CKD) or significantly impaired kidney function should moderate protein intake under medical supervision, as excessive protein may accelerate decline in already compromised kidneys - typical recommendations for CKD patients range from 0.6-0.8g/kg depending on disease stage. Other concerns about high protein intake have been largely refuted: bone health is not harmed and may be improved by adequate protein through enhanced calcium absorption; liver health is not negatively affected in healthy individuals; cancer risk is not increased by protein intake itself, though certain preparation methods (charring, excessive processed meats) may introduce problematic compounds. The key is maintaining adequate hydration (35-40ml per kg body weight daily) to support nitrogen waste excretion, choosing quality protein sources emphasizing fish, poultry, eggs, dairy, and plant proteins while moderating heavily processed and charred meats, and ensuring balanced nutrition rather than excessive protein displacing other important nutrients like fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.

faqs.question: What is the best timing for protein intake to maximize muscle growth and recovery?
faqs.answer: Protein timing strategies can optimize muscle protein synthesis and recovery, though total daily protein intake remains more important than precise timing for most individuals. The post-workout anabolic window, traditionally thought to be a narrow 30-60 minute period, is now understood to extend 3-6 hours or longer, particularly when pre-workout protein was consumed - this means moderate flexibility in post-workout nutrition without compromising results. That said, consuming 20-40 grams of high-quality protein within 2 hours post-exercise enhances recovery and muscle protein synthesis, with fast-absorbing proteins like whey being particularly effective immediately post-workout. Protein distribution throughout the day significantly impacts total daily muscle protein synthesis - consuming 20-40 grams of protein across 4-5 meals stimulates muscle protein synthesis more effectively than consuming the same total amount in 1-2 large meals, as each protein-rich meal restarts the muscle protein synthesis machinery. Pre-sleep protein consumption (30-40 grams of slow-digesting protein like casein, Greek yogurt, or cottage cheese) can enhance overnight muscle protein synthesis by providing sustained amino acid release during the 8-10 hour sleep period, improving next-day recovery. Pre-workout protein (20-30 grams consumed 1-2 hours before training) elevates blood amino acid levels during and after exercise, potentially reducing muscle protein breakdown and enhancing the post-workout anabolic response. For optimal results, prioritize these timing strategies in order of importance: 1) total daily protein intake meeting your needs (1.6-2.2g/kg), 2) even distribution across 4-5 meals with 20-40g per meal, 3) pre-sleep protein for overnight support, 4) post-workout protein within 2-3 hours of training, and 5) pre-workout protein if training fasted or more than 4 hours after last meal.

faqs.question: Can you build muscle on a plant-based diet, and how do plant proteins compare to animal proteins?
faqs.answer: Building muscle on a plant-based diet is absolutely achievable, though it requires more strategic planning than omnivorous approaches due to differences in protein quality, digestibility, and amino acid profiles between plant and animal sources. The main challenges with plant proteins include lower leucine content (most plant proteins provide 1.0-1.8g leucine per 30g protein versus 2.5-3g in animal proteins), incomplete amino acid profiles in many single plant sources (lacking one or more essential amino acids), and lower digestibility (70-85% for most plant proteins versus 90-95% for animal proteins). To successfully build muscle on plant-based nutrition, implement these evidence-based strategies: increase total protein intake by 10-20% compared to omnivorous recommendations (targeting 1.8-2.4g/kg versus 1.6-2.2g/kg) to compensate for lower digestibility and amino acid quality; combine complementary plant proteins throughout the day to ensure all essential amino acids are adequately represented (beans with rice, hummus with pita, peanut butter with whole grain bread); emphasize complete or near-complete plant proteins like quinoa, soy products (tofu, tempeh, edamame), buckwheat, and hemp seeds; consider plant-based protein supplements (pea, soy, rice, or blended plant proteins) to easily increase protein intake and ensure adequate leucine per meal; distribute protein across 4-6 meals to repeatedly stimulate muscle protein synthesis throughout the day; and potentially supplement with individual amino acids like leucine (2.5-3g per meal) to reach the leucine threshold for optimal muscle protein synthesis. Research comparing vegan and omnivorous diets with matched protein intake shows similar muscle growth when these strategies are implemented, demonstrating that the total amount and distribution of protein matters more than the specific source, provided all essential amino acids are adequately supplied.
